10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:16): I'm working on an ambitious startup to collect, rank & search all html5 mobile apps.  If anyone is interested, PM me.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:17): make it look sleek and get twitter to do the rest =)
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:18): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b: i like the way you think.  Marketing hooks are a requirement
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:18): and UX has to be extremely intuitive, and fun
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:19): the only way an aggregator can succeed is to make people feel their contributions aren't contributions.
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:20): right: they have to benefit from their own contributions

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:20): make it sleek, make adding apps you heard of a one click process, reviews without login (but added weight to reviews by proper users), and you can get some good momentum going.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:20): and make sure the name isn't a common word that gets lost in the search engines
0fe8692be7a494c6561f745b9f3b0d17 (00:21): i'm glad to see G+ api allowing to specify exactly what is desired to return
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:21): or your runup to fame will be cut short by people not being able to google for it
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:22): what about the notion of invite only to start?
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:22): you prefer open? why?
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:24): because if I have to take the effort to help you out, I have better things to do with my time.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:25): unless you have something really cool to offer, there's no reward for me as a user to go through the effort of trying to get in

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:25): and having a more convenient place to find html5 apps, when it's just starting up, is not rewarding. it's only the promise of a reward later on, when enough people have helped you build it up.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:25): so invite only is great if you already have a considerable product sitting behind the login portal.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (00:26): but for a crowd sourced site... probably not the right model.

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:49): 10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee - what is and isn't an "html5 mobile app"?

10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:52): f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905: good q.  the way you define an app vs a mobile site, is up for debate, but an app usually "does" something, where a mobile site may be more informational.  is that what you were asking?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:52): actually I'm asking about all 3 terms
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:52): what makes a site "html5" in your opinion vs not?
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:52): is just using the HTML5 doctype enough?
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:52): technically yes, practically no
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:53): it is html5, but any old website can do that and it offers nothing new
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:54): so what makes the difference then as far as inclusion in such a "directory"?
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:54): so to qualify it as html5, the aggregation algrythm i built out does some fancier stuff like analyze to what extent a page uses new html5 functionality

f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:54): and what makes a site "mobile"? you may want to take a look at Jeremy Keith's recent presentation "There Is No Mobile Web" and related blog posts: http://adactio.com/journal/4860/ and http://adactio.com/journal/4862/
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (00:55): he also touches in that first blog post about the problem with labeling something a "web app"
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:56): all good points.
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:57): i think it further underlines the need for separating the old from the new
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (00:58): since old content is loosing relevancy in the mobile environment (desk vs. line at super market)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:01): why not characterize it as "flexible" environment rather than "mobile"?
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:02): yea sure!
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:02): or, given how people make mobile sites, "sparse" vs. "full"
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:03): where sparse usually means good content/copy design, and full means noisy and full of crap that wastes bandwidth and no one looks at?
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:03): i think mobile content will be richer than desktop content
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:03): I say flexible rather than mobile because the #/range/uses of mobile devices has exploded
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:04): I've seen the opposite too, where mobile means "useless" and real means "Actually showing images"
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:04): exactly the kinds of quality filtering mobile needs
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:05): i stick with calling mobile because i think when mobile the mindset is different

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:05): if you're in a modern western country, say, and you're on an unlimited or too-much-to-user-per-month data plan, you don't care about saving b/w. You want a good looking webapp or site.
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:05): biggest resource on smartphones? Time.
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:05): you don't want to waste the user's time
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:05): with 1ghz+ procs, time is fast becoming irrelevant too
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:06): navigation vs use time, though, yes. you want to drive down the first while keeping the second high
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:06): but that's the first principle of user interface design, really.
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:08): so you're saying the same website should be shared across all devices
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:08): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b - I've seen dumbed down "mobile" sites too and they're quite annoying.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:08): You can't assume mobile means fast - even in western countries.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:08): The networks fail and lag all the time.
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:09): yes. network issues will remain, and possible grow.  that's where tools like HTML5 cache and storage come to play
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:10): e.g. slow connections: conferences, dialup, third world, rural cell coverage, urban subways/BART, protests, disasters.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:10): 10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee - yes - was responding to 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b's idealistic assessment of a "a modern western country"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:10): I'm not touching third world. The way the web and mobiles are user there is so radically different that I simply don't understand their use model.
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:10): *are used
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:10): you have to care about bandwidth
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:11): even in "a modern western country"
0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:11): true, but you shouldn't sacrifice content over it too readily
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:11): otherwise your app/site/page sucks
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:11): for the same reason, you can't depend on Javascript either (assuming you're designing for "flexible/mobile" rather than desktop/hardline environments)
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:12): e.g. what happens on a slow network when users click an AJAX #!-link before the JS loads? nothing. slow net is like JS-off.

0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b (01:12): it's particularly interesting when tablets are involved. Opening a site on an ipad or samsung galaxy over wifi and discovering it picked the mobile version for you is infuriating
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:12): yes- this is a transition period
10af6afd5b4cecd7f17a94fba46fc2ee (01:13): everyone's experimenting trying to define the way to do things
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:13): 0de37da1d654c10aed33d7b7347b8e3b - hence why "mobile version" is bad design
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:13): clean and flexible design works everywhere, mobile, desktop, tablet etc.
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:13): The new Boston Globe design is a good example
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:14): Jeremy's blog post discusses it: http://adactio.com/journal/4862/
f5af272b5b04154c260eec46f4deb905 (01:14): and the clincher at the bottom of the post - the new Boston Globe even works reasonably on the old Apple Newton
